sn4.22:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans near Silāvatī.
sn4.22:4.2: Now at that time Venerable Samiddhi was meditating not far from the Buddha, diligent, keen, and resolute.
sn4.22:4.3: Then as Venerable Samiddhi was in private solitude this thought came to his mind:
sn4.22:4.4: “I’m so fortunate, so very fortunate, to have a teacher who is a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha!
sn4.22:4.5: I’m so fortunate, so very fortunate, to have gone forth in a teaching and training so well explained!
sn4.22:4.6: “I’m so fortunate, so very fortunate, to have spiritual companions who are ethical and of good character.”
sn4.22:4.7: And then Māra the Wicked, knowing what Samiddha was thinking, went up to him
sn4.22:4.8: and made a terrifyingly loud noise close by him. It seemed as if the earth was shattering.
sn4.22:5.1: Then Samiddhi went up to the Buddha,
sn4.22:5.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn4.22:5.3: and told him what had happened. The Buddha said:
sn4.22:6.2: That’s Māra the Wicked come to pull the wool over your eyes!
sn4.22:6.3: Go back to that same place, Samiddhi, and meditate, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
sn4.22:6.4: “Yes, sir,” replied Samiddhi. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
sn4.22:6.5: And for a second time Samiddhi was meditating in that same place, diligent, ardent, and resolute.
sn4.22:6.6: And for a second time he had the same thought …
sn4.22:6.7: and Māra made an earth-shattering noise.
sn4.22:6.9: Then Samiddhi addressed Māra the Wicked One in verse:
sn4.22:7.2: from the lay life to homelessness.
sn4.22:7.3: My mindfulness and wisdom are mature,
sn4.22:7.4: my mind is serene in samādhi.
sn4.22:8.1: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The mendicant Samiddhi knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
